description: From Old English font, an early borrowing from Latin fōns, fontis (“fountain”).

entries.meaning: (Christianity) A receptacle in a church for holy water, especially one used in baptism.
A receptacle for oil in a lamp.

description: Borrowed from Middle French fonte, feminine past participle of verb fondre (“to melt”).

definitionGroups.group: (typography) A set of glyphs of unified design, belonging to one typeface (e.g., Helvetica), style (e.g., italic), and weight (e.g., bold). Usually representing the letters of an alphabet and its supplementary characters.

entries.meaning: In metal typesetting, a set of type sorts in one size.
In phototypesetting, a set of patterns forming glyphs of any size, or the film they are stored on.
In digital typesetting, a set of glyphs in a single style, representing one or more alphabets or writing systems, or the computer code representing it.
(computing, typography) A computer file containing the code used to draw and compose the glyphs of one or more typographic fonts on a computer display or printer.

verbs.description: font (third-person singular simple present fonts, present participle fonting, simple past and past participle fonted)

entries.meaning: (television, colloquial, transitive) To overlay (text) on the picture.
examples: When figures or quotes are thought helpful to understanding a spot, they're "fonted" over the cover picture.

description: Apparently from fount, with influence from the senses above (under etymology 1).

examples: A gaudy taste; for they are little skill'd inThe arts of which these lands were once the font
